abstract.p: Residents of Manhattan's Chinatown, citing pollution and noise, attend Community Board meeting about Atlantic City casino buses that load and unload at Bowery and Division Street; Mayor's office plans multidepartment meeting on how to better regulate Chinatown transportation; photo (M)

block.p: Around 8:30 p.m., a fat gray bus bound for Atlantic City pulls up on Division Street in Chinatown. Its doors wheeze open, and a line of riders shuffle into formation, clutching pink tickets and plastic shopping bags, and sucking a few final drags from their cigarettes before flicking them away.

The ritual takes no more than 15 minutes, but it happens dozens of times a day as buses headed to Trump Plaza, Foxwoods or other casinos load and unload passengers in the V formed by the Bowery and Division Street.

Around 8:30 p.m., a fat gray bus bound for Atlantic City pulls up on Division Street in Chinatown. Its doors wheeze open, and a line of riders shuffle into formation, clutching pink tickets and plastic shopping bags, and sucking a few final drags from their cigarettes before flicking them away.

The ritual takes no more than 15 minutes, but it happens dozens of times a day as buses headed to Trump Plaza, Foxwoods or other casinos load and unload passengers in the V formed by the Bowery and Division Street.
Now, citing pollution and noise, neighbors say they want the buses to find a new home.
''You can feel a toxic film in our yard,'' said Justin Yu, vice president of the co-op board at Confucius Plaza, a 44-story complex that overlooks the site. ''It's very unhealthy.''

While numerous bus companies operate out of Chinatown, Mr. Yu and his neighbors are particularly concerned about casino buses because their informal hub is a block shared by hundreds of senior citizens, an elementary school, a kindergarten and a day care center.
And unlike the commuter buses that travel to and from Boston or Philadelphia, he said, they offer little public benefit.
''Casino buses take money out of the community,'' Mr. Yu said, and attract an ''undesirable element.''
Alice Hom, principal of Public School 124, which abuts the site, said the bus users often litter or urinate on the street. Teachers complain about fumes seeping into their classrooms.

On Wednesday afternoon, fifth graders in the P.S. 124 after-school program sat in clusters on the floor, drawing pictures of buses spewing curls of Magic Marker smoke, to be displayed at a community board meeting that night.
''The exhaust pollutes the air, which causes serious damage to the ozone layer,'' said Andrea Ting, a 10-year-old wearing black nail polish and polka-dot arm warmers. ''It's really a problem.''

May Chow, a resident of Confucius Plaza who has operated Chinatown casino buses since 1979, sighed when she heard about the drawings. The children are ''being used,'' she said, adding, ''They're being brainwashed.''
Ms. Chow, who runs eight buses a day from Division Street to Caesars Atlantic City, acknowledges that her drivers sometimes double-park but says they never idle their engines.
Though she has agreed to consider alternate locations, she says she is reluctant to move from a spot her customers know and trust.

Ms. Chow and 16 other casino bus operators recently formed a coalition and hired a lawyer, Steven Friedberg, who at the community board meeting described his clients as responsible citizens willing to police themselves.

The audience seemed unconvinced. After speeches from neighbors and parents, Lolita Jackson, Manhattan director of the Mayor's Community Assistance Unit, announced plans for a multidepartment meeting this week on how to better regulate Chinatown transportation.
Speaking last, Ms. Chow stood firm. ''I'm not going to argue with what was said in this room,'' she said. ''Nobody likes buses. But this is city life.''
CASSI FELDMAN
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN
